title: Thursday, 24th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

I tee-ed up a pic, but I don't think it's suitable

PM11:01am

Pictures of actual dead cats will get me in trouble

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Have this big fight instead

PM11:01am

PM11:02am

You a big boxing fan Bryce?

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Cardiff is a huge fan of MMA

PM11:02am

When we hired him he cleared it in advance -- that the FT was happy hiring a huge MMA fan

PM11:03am

I said 'sure, why not?' Broah church here

11:03 am
PM11:03am

And that was before i got my divesity training

PM11:03am

Long before

PM11:03am

Murad saying that this is going to be a bigger $$$$ bout than any previously

11:03 am
PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-bf50-e1c239b45787

PM11:04am

But he doesn't go for the big figure that some people are talking about

PM11:04am

Which is $1bn. Which is nuts

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Shall i keep filling pink space?

PM11:05am

Have the 'smart' salt shaker

PM11:05am

Dumbest thing of the year to date

11:05 am
PM11:05am

BE11:05am

Oh, that thing. Assumed it was a joke. Apparently not.

PM11:05am

It's a salt shaker you can talk to or communicate with your smart phone

11:05 am
PM11:05am

The Verge has full details

PM11:06am

https://www.thever...p-alexa-smartphone

undefined
11:06 am
PM11:06am

So, run through the dead cats

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 797.00, up 136 (+20.57%), High: 806.96, Low: 587.37, Volume: 4.34m
PM11:06am

Omg smile

11:06 am
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,446, up 25.84 (+1.82%), High: 1,467, Low: 1,405, Volume: 4.58m
PM11:06am

Omg smile

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 45.80, up 3.24 (+7.61%), High: 46.25, Low: 42.82, Volume: 3.43m
11:06 am
PM11:07am

Omg smile

PM11:07am

And preview tomorrow's deadcat

PM11:07am

Maybe

11:07 am
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 178.90, down 56.4 (-23.97%), High: 190.00, Low: 155.40, Volume: 28.90m
BE11:07am

Okay, this is as good a place to start as any.

PM11:07am

Things really are being punished

11:07 am
BE11:08am

And it's one of the themes of the summer, if I may.

BE11:08am

Which is long-standing issues suddenly blowing up.

BE11:09am

How long have we been banging on about the problems with sticking Carphone's rather complicated revenue recognition policy together with Dixons' rather simple one?

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Quite a while!

BE11:09am

Since the day of the merger, if I remember correctly.

BE11:09am

And today, that concern goes front and centre.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Scorchedfingers

BE11:09am

It's a three-part warning but the most important bit is the EU roaming charges bit.

BE11:10am

Geoff Ruddell of Morgan Stanley explains how this all works.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

btw trading statement here https://www.invest...1708240700048375O/

PM11:10am

But yeah, MS...

BE11:11am

- The key news here is the receivables revaluation on the Carphone side of the business. This is primarily a technical accounting issue. When Carphone sells a handset its revenues come from getting a share of arpu for as long as it stays connected. Carphone makes an estimate as to what revenues this will generate and takes these revenues upfront (we have flagged this before in our note Why DCFis the right way to value CPW). Typically Carphone has made one-off adjustments to these receivables related to mobile network debtors for 'out of bundle spends'and EU roaming charges make up a significant part of these spends. As a consequence of the changes to EU roaming legislation Dixons Carphone estimates the negative impact for FY17/18 profits to be in the region of £10m-£40m.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Which is an issue highlighted by MOST, and also most memorably by Exane in the note from a week ago that went hard on Dixons' questionable quality of revenue.

BE11:12am

And we'll come back to roaming, but there are wider issues flagged.

PM11:13am

Go on

11:13 am
BE11:13am

As in, "more challenging" postpay mobile phone market.

BE11:14am

Which can be blamed on handset prices continuing to go both higher and lower. There's a top end and a bottom end and people who don't want the former tend to be fine with the latter.

BE11:14am

And second, there's a change to Honeybee, the Carphone consulting thingmy, which is now SAAS so is going to make less money.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Let me disappear back into sellside to get some kind of grasp on where forecasts are going.

BE11:15am

Investec .............

BE11:16am

Expectations likely to fall materially: Piecing all of this together, we would expect consensus PBT to fall c. £100m / c. 20% at the mid-point of guidance (£360-440m), vs £501m reported for FY17. In getting to this, we would estimate -£15m from the recent Spanish disposal last year, -£30-60m from the change in expectations in mobile true-ups, -£15-25m from mobile’s underperformance and c. -£20m from Honeybee. Recommendation, forecasts and TP are under review.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

And Stifel .....

BE11:16am

Actually, Stifel's very readable on the postpay thing.

BE11:17am

The postpay mobile market is increasingly competitive. Consumers are baulking at automatically upgrading to increasingly expensive handsets that offer little perceived incremental utility (probably exacerbated by weak £). As a result, consumers are holding onto handsets for longer periods and opting for cheap SIM-only deals. Alongside this, Dixons has a commitment with the network operators to deliver a certain number of connections. This has led to a degree of price pressure on the phone retail business in order to achieve targets. The group believes there is a limit to the phone life-cycle extension process as hardware does degrade over time. While not helpful to overall retail profits, the group is guiding to flat overall profits in the “core retail” operations.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

£480m PBT falls to midpoint of £400m: Management is guiding to a FY18 PBT range of £360-440m in FY18 (midpoint £400m, c.27p EPS). The shares have been very weak into the statement but the degree of the downgrade, relatively soon after the late June final results, will undoubtedly unnerve investors. The next scheduled newsflow is not until 13 December but we think the group would be wise to hold an Investor Relations event in the near term, in order to increase visibility around a number of significant profit factors.

PM11:18am

Nice request for more info there

BE11:18am

That's part of the problem here.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Folk have been increasingly nervous about Dixons this year, as the price demonstrates, and that Exane note referred to earlier crystallised the various things to worry about.

BE11:20am

Today's warning -- which is mostly an accounting issue, plus a bit of market shift that anyone who's been down the high street could see -- isn't in itself terribly dramatic.

BE11:20am

But Dixons seems not to have a hold on how to present it.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

You can make an argument to knife catch though, which is what RBC does.

PM11:21am

Brave of RBC

BE11:21am

Dixons Carphone has sharply de-rated recently, mainly we think
on concerns over the outlook for UK hardlines, mobile headwinds and as the timing of cashflow improvement has been pushed out. However, electricals trends remain robust, DC maintains a strong market position, valuation is very undemanding and it offers the potential for higher cash returns, which have already started to increase (DPS +15% yoy in FY17).

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Target goes to 325p from 350p.

PM11:21am

Really?

BE11:22am

Aye.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Although the mobile category faces headwinds it accounts for 35% of UK revenue (electricals is over half) and should be less cyclical. Carphone maintains its position as the only independent retailer of scale able to offer the full range of handsets and network options.

BE11:22am

Cashflow improvement deferred, but should be when, not if: Earlier this year our thesis was that Dixons Carphone would see a step change up in its net cash generation given falling capex and lower merger restructuring costs. However, any boost to cashflow from this is likely to be offset by outflows on the mobile side of the business, owing to the higher cost of handsets and changes in network mix. As such, we now look for a more stable trend in net debt this year with a gradual reduction from FY19 onwards. This should allow for an acceleration in higher cash returns (dividend yield now close to 5%). Also DC's relatively large pension deficit (c.£570mn) should benefit from up to date mortality rates, which could boost PBT by c.4%.

BE11:23am

Reducing EPS forecasts by 3-4%, PT 350p to 325p. We have reduced our EPS forecasts by 3-4%, mainly owing to the dilutive effect of the recent disposal of The Phone House business in Spain. DC saw a net £25mn benefit last year from large oneoffs on electrical warranty and mobile insurance agreements. Despite this and mobile headwinds, we believe it can offset this by taking share in UK electricals (including from independents and supermarkets), through cost savings eg lower rents (average lease length 5 years) and growing its Nordic and southern Europe businesses.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Whatever happened to that chap who revived Dixons (pre-merger) and then went off to Apple, only to be fired six months later?

PM11:24am

John Browett?

BE11:24am

Oh ...... no idea.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Felt sorry for him -- cos he actually did a terrific job at Dixons, back then

PM11:24am

Completely changed the sales atmosphere in-store

PM11:25am

All gone back to how it used to be of course, since then...

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Oh he's at Dunelm

PM11:25am

Quietly gone into home furnishings

PM11:25am

Sounds dull. Maybe he needed that after the Apple trauma

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Apple shops are horrible places to be and actually buying anything in them is extraordinarily difficult. I've never understood the fascination with them.

PM11:26am

You just march up to a staff member -- buy what you need and get the hell out

BE11:26am

........... Anyway, RBC (and yeah, I should have made clear that note quoted above is a bit stale) also has a bit about telco readthrough.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

In short, there's not much.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 219.98, down 0.268 (-0.12%), High: 220.90, Low: 219.45, Volume: 6.20m
BE11:27am

We think the main issue is the launch schedule of market leaders Samsung and Apple (NB. Samsung launched its Note 8 phone today and Apple is reported to be launching its iPhone 8 on Sept 12). As a result, consumers are delaying upgrading handsets, to either get the “new new” thing, or take advantage of the knock-on effect on prices of older-generation phones.

11:27 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 292.28, down 0.725 (-0.25%), High: 293.55, Low: 291.80, Volume: 1.70m
BE11:27am

There are obvious diminishing returns to the level of technological improvement in each new generation of phones, meaning existing older phones are capable of running all the high-end apps currently available. With no “killer app” that can only run on the latest model, there is less demand for the very latest model.

BE11:27am

There is also likely to have been a mix effect, due to a higher proportion of SIM-free phones reflecting the increase in SIM-only tariffs in the market. This disproportionately affects retailers such as Dixons.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Impact on Telcos: We think the impact is muted for the network operators. While retailers such as Dixons want (and encourage) churn as they make a margin on the sale, network operators have the opposite incentives, wanting to reduce churn, as it is a significant SAC cost.
Indeed, the lower postpaid sales boost profits (less handset cost, less SAC/subsidy), and we expect some phasing linked to the launch schedule. As BT’s CFO pointed out at the fiscal 1Q results: “EE EBITDA was up 19% in the quarter to June driven by revenue growth in a slower handset market, which improved indirect costs. I should caution that we don't expect this level of EBITDA growth to continue throughout the year, partly due to the impact of EU roaming cuts and partly because we expect to bear the cost with significant handset launches later in the year.”
Longer term, if this lower churn environment continues (BT reported 1.1% postpaid churn in 1Q18), and the average handset lasts longer, then we would expect it to be positive for the network operators (but obviously negative for retailers such as Dixons). We do not believe the impact on the network’s own stores (eg, BT will have nearly 700 stores within 2 years incl. Sainsbury's) is material as they are primarily designed to maintain/increase share.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 197.80, up 1.3 (+0.66%), High: 198.70, Low: 195.80, Volume: 207.25k
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 955.36, up 1.36 (+0.14%), High: 956.00, Low: 949.50, Volume: 154.31k
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Any other MVNOs out there?

BE11:28am

Oh, The People's Operator. That's one.

People's Operator PLC (TPOP:LSE): Last: 2.00, no change, Volume: 0.00
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Unlikely to be affected given it has nearly no customers, I guess. Defensive, in context.

undefined
PM11:30am

Quick reminder: August rules apply. If/when we run out of things to say, we will have run out of things to say

11:00 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Dead Cat day here on Markets Live

BE11:30am

Well, as you noted earlier, this dead cat in Provident is extending into a second day.

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 795.43, up 134.43 (+20.34%), High: 806.96, Low: 587.37, Volume: 4.62m
11:31 am
BE11:31am

20%! Cripes! So it seems to be on the top of the daily most-bought lists among the retail brokers, as usually happens.

BE11:32am

And some of the retail-aimed reporting has been ......

BE11:32am

Okay, well. I'm not picking this out for specific criticism, to be clear. It's just an example of what's being consumed.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

https://www.shares...rovident-financial

BE11:32am

[I]nvestment bank JP Morgan Cavenove is convinced you can make money by owning the shares. It has a £32 price target on the stock, implying nearly 500% upside.

BE11:33am

Which isn't entirely fair, as it was written off JPM's 8:28am note on the day of the warning. That note does nothing more than put the RNS in a digestible form.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

JPM's proper note, which was signed off less than an hour later, was (needless to say) a downgrade.

BE11:33am

In aggregate we cut our group earnings estimates for 17/18/19 by 66%/52%/45%, respectively, and reduce our SoTP Dec-18 TP to 1,200p (was 3,200p). While our TP offers upside, we downgrade to N from OW reflecting pending uncertainty from a business and regulatory perspective, and the associated challenges in determining value at this stage.

BE11:33am

That kind of thing.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

In our revised SOTP valuation methodology, we give zero value to HC and reduce our assumed P/E multiples for Vanquis from 16x to 10x, reflecting pending regulatory uncertainty. While MoneyBarn is unaffected by the changes, we believe it is prudent to bring down the multiple in this business from 14x to 10x.

BE11:34am

You can make a buy case. The best I've read of late was via Numis.

BE11:35am

Which I think was yesterday, or possibly even Tuesday afternoon.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We see the PRA ring-fencing the capital of Vanquis and the compensation could see the business runs short of capital and/or liquidity. We believe both Home Credit and Vanquis should be able to make a sustainably attractive ROE and, assuming the solvency of the business isn’t called into question, the shares are attractive. We doubt there will be much in the way of good news in the short term and given the risks our COE has increased materially. For the brave, Provident is a Buy at this price, valued at a historic PE (not that we expect earnings to recover to the 2016 number in the near future, they could recover to this level over a few years) of just 3x.

BE11:35am

....... which is the Woodford argument, of course, albeit a more refined version of it. Cheap at normalised earnings.

BE11:36am

Against that I'd chuck in a couple of caveats.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So Provident has headroom on committed facilities of £204m as of end June 2017.

BE11:36am

But also a £120m retail bond maturity in October.

BE11:36am

And, according to Liberum, another £230m of retail deposits maturing by the end of June 2018. This is their table:

11:36 am
BE11:36am

BE11:37am

... which is a funding shortfall on reasonably optimistic numbers.

BE11:37am

Numbers that depend firstly on a CEO-less group that's issued two profit warnings not issuing a third profit warning.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

And secondly on the FCA not demanding compensation for customers of its Vanquis sub-prime PPI thing, which to remind has been worth c.£70m pa revenue.

BE11:37am

What's reasonable there? Or even plausible? Two years of clawback would be a (£140m) to build into the table.

BE11:38am

Note also that sub-prime PPI is just one area where the FCA's taking a look at Provident.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

oh really?

BE11:38am

FCA doesn't seem to have updated its website in a bit, irritatingly, so you need to go through the table search thing. https://www.fca.or...n/thematic-reviews

BE11:39am

But I'm told that if you dig through that, there's an FCA review of high-cost credit, an FCA consultation on collection agent incentives and an FCA review on giving doorsteppers temporary authorisation. All of which could have implications for Provident.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

That's why most of the sellside have targets rather higher than Provident's current share price, but also have neutral or sell recommendations.

BE11:40am

Historically, it looks cheap! But historically, it's had sufficient capital and liquidity to operate. That might not forever be true.

PM11:40am

So the basic advice here is: avoid. No getting round that

11:40 am
undefined
PM11:41am

This Revolution Bars thing is trading up through the terms -- but not dramatically so

PM11:41am

203p cash terms here https://www.invest...1708240700048438O/

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Market..

Revolution Bars Group PLC (RBG:LSE): Last: 208.01, up 22.26 (+11.98%), High: 209.00, Low: 205.00, Volume: 6.74m
PM11:42am

We have no fresh intel on a counter

11:42 am
BE11:42am

It's Deltic, isn't it? The old Luminar. I must admit to not having read the story this morning.

PM11:42am

203p itself from Stonegate is a slight bump from the indicated level

BE11:43am

Hang on, let me get Brumby to catch us up. I've lost track here.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Stonegegate's 203p per share cash bid for Revolution has been accepted, valuing the latter at £101.5m and representing a 62.4% premium to Revolution's 125p share price just before Stonegate's bid. Commenting on the Offer, Keith Edelman, non-executive chairman of Revolution, said: 'We believe that the offer from Stonegate represents an attractive and certain value in cash today for Revolution Shareholders, reflecting the high quality of the business, its people, market position and future prospects... Stonegate is an experienced operator in this sector that understands Revolution's ethos with its unique premium bar offering.'

PM11:43am

Ah, Deltic have due diligence access

PM11:43am

This ain't over yet

11:43 am
PM11:43am

https://www.invest...1708240734038700O/

PM11:44am

Deltic notes the announcement made on 24 August, 2017 by Stonegate Pub Company Limited ("Stonegate") of a firm intention to make an offer for Revolution at a price of 203p per share. Deltic continues to believe that this offer significantly undervalues Revolution.

BE11:44am

Wait, hang on, the Deltic pitch has suddenly become a "possible" cash offer?

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Since when does Deltic have cash? The idea was to vertically integrate places for students to get ratarsed, wasn't it?

BE11:46am

As in, issue lots of paper to try and get costs out of the business by runining terrible bars alongside terrible nightclubs.

BE11:46am

I await this Deltic "cash" offer with interest. But I won't hold my breath.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Anyway, I think Canaccord is alone in covering Revolution now and they've not written anything yet so we can't really add much.

undefined
BE11:48am

Sellside wise, there's an Exane downgrade of Easyjet around

11:48 am
BE11:48am

.... which I've not managed to get hold of, because Exane's gone full Mifid II paywall recently.

BE11:48am

Here's the cover page.

BE11:48am

As transport analysts we expect to get asked a lot of
questions about capacity and unit revenues/costs. Yet we
feel these subjects are hogging too much of the limelight
and our answers are based on a host of other factors.
Pivotal issues such as demand, route overlaps, jet fuel
and strategy, not to mention correlations between key
metrics, warrant more systematic analysis. To this end,
we unveil our Airlines Abacus, a recurrent publication
covering areas we consider important, with bull/bear
signals for the industry thrown in for good measure.
Our inaugural edition considers the higher risk but
superior upside of legacy players vs. LCCs. We are fans
of IAG and Lufthansa, and still like Ryanair, but
downgrade easyJet to Underperform.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Beyond that, I know nothing until someone sends me the PDF. And now they get reminded they pay for it, people don't seem to do that as much.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,225, down 45 (-3.54%), High: 1,251, Low: 1,219, Volume: 1.14m
undefined
11:50 am
BE11:50am

.................... elsewhere ...........................

PM11:51am

(It's a real clampdown at Exane. V v tight distribution -- which is a shame for us, cos their analysts have been shooting up the rankings. Will be interesting to see how their rankings fair going forward.)

PM11:51am

(Genuinely interesting. We don't know, one way or another.)

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Residual -- not false alarm. You'll just have to be patient. Look at at the end of the month.)

BE11:52am

I've forgotten what's been requested: ROTR, please remind me. In the meantime, couple of decent strategy things out.

BE11:53am

For example, Andrew Lapthorne at SocGen says share buybacks are crap.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

We find no evidence that buying back shares boosts a company's share price. We also find that over time companies that buy back their shares tend to be the weakest and cheapest (relative to their peers) in the market. They exhibit weak relative price momentum and generally have ‘below average strength' balance sheets. More worryingly today, the companies that have been buying back most of their market cap during the past 12 months are most highly correlated to the higher beta, highly cyclical and highly leveraged companies. These findings back up our long held view that companies buy shares back because their business is weak, not strong.

BE11:53am

A re-examination of buyback-based indices (i.e. those based on companies that have already bought back their shares) reaffirms our previous analysis that buyback yield (and most variations thereof) is simply a sub-component of free cashflow yield. The buyback factor is simply a proxy for the ‘value' factor, and beyond that there is no alpha in it at all.

This is not to say that buybacks have not benefitted the equity market overall. If your shares are bought off you, then you typically need to reinvest them, and we estimate that the US has had 17.5% of its market cap bought back over the past 6 years. Ironically, given that buybacks are usually done by below average quality companies, this may also provide investors with an excuse for an exit. The proceeds may be recycled into a better performing asset. Buybacks may boost the market, but they do not obviously benefit those companies doing it.

The gross buyback total has been falling at a rate of 20% pa, yet even after that, annualised buybacks still exceed $500bn. With balance sheets already stretched and with evidence that it is weak companies that do most of the buybacks, more buyback cuts are likely.

PM11:54am

Lapthorne is always an interesting read

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Well, most of the time he is

BE11:55am

It's familiar stuff, but very well presented.

BE11:55am

11:54 am
BE11:55am

(@GBKrona: true.)

undefined
BE11:55am

......... eesh, Genel requested. Genel.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

I worry about you sometimes, ROTR. In a universe of investment possibilities you end up with .... anyway .......

Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 137.50, up 7.5 (+5.77%), High: 142.00, Low: 128.50, Volume: 1.38m
BE11:56am

So this is on the Kurdistan pay settlement

11:57 am
BE11:57am

DNO also popped.

Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 98.88, up 5.63 (+6.03%), High: 102.00, Low: 94.25, Volume: 716.47k
BE11:57am

Yep, GKP nearly back to 1p in old money.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Let me get RBC to summarise here.

BE11:58am

The Kurdistan-focused names – DNO and Genel – have this morning announced a landmark agreement with the KRG, resolving the issues associated with outstanding receivables - the deals reduce the significant uncertainty on asset values and future cash flows.
The net impact should be an increase in corporate valuations driven directly by higher equity stakes, plus a greater commitment by the companies to invest in their existing fields; netted off this increase will be the risked and heavily discounted future receivables. We expect both stocks to be marked higher today – this should represent a marked reversal in DNO’s initial performance this morning; bondholders should also gain confidence too.
DNO has been assigned the 20% interest in the Tawke licence held by the KRG as part of a landmark settlement of outstanding receivables owed to the company for past crude oil deliveries. Following the settlement, DNO holds a 75% operated stake in the licence containing the Tawke and Peshkabir fields with combined proven and probable reserves in excess of 500mmbbl and production in excess of 100,000b/d. DNO has settled its claims for all outstanding Tawke licence receivables from the Government and the Government has exercised its Tawke licence audit rights to its satisfaction for the period up to the effective date and has no adjustment claims. The Government has also discharged DNO from certain payment obligations including production bonuses, licence fees and a USD 150 million water purification project that is no longer required by the Government.

Genel will receive 4.5% of Tawke gross field revenues for the five-year period from 1 August 2017 to 31 July 2022; Genel’s capacity building payments on the profit-share element of its Tawke entitlement will be eliminated over the entire life of the Tawke field. Outstanding production bonuses and PSC liabilities on the Taq Taq and Tawke fields totalling ~$30m net to Genel have been set off against the receivable and, as a result, are no longer payable. Proceeds received for current sales from the Taq Taq field will continue to be liable for CBP.

BE11:59am

(@ESM: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ )

11:59 am
undefined
BE12:00pm

Through midday but we may as well do Greencore as well, since it's requested.

BE12:01pm

Came off sharply yesterday, bouncing it into a statement saying all's well. Sort of.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

So, brace yourself here. It seems the selloff was triggered by word that Greencore had stopped production of "frozen breakfast products" for a big US coffee chain.

BE12:02pm

What's a frozen breakfast product? I don't know. I don't want to know. Anyway, disruption minimal apparently.

BE12:03pm

Here's Numis.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Greencore's shares have fallen c.8% in the last week and are down 16% YTD. In response to the recent share price weakness Greencore has put out a statement that should provide reassurance. Greencore confirms that there is no change to its outlook and that the integration of its US business is on track. It also remains encouraged by the pipeline of commercial opportunities in the US. It notes that it has lost some Frozen business from its Jacksonville site but the profit impact is minimal and will allow the company refocus on fresh products at the site. We make no change to forecasts. We think the current valuation of 12.8x PE and 10.8x EV/ EBITDA for CY 2017 is attractive for a stock that offers good structural growth and improving FCF generation. Reiterate Buy rating and 300p TP.

The company has stated that there is no change to the outlook
statement given at the Q3 update on 27 July. However, the
company has lost business in the legacy retail business in the US
(c£70m with Starbucks = c2.5% of group sales). As a result, the
company will refocus its Jacksonville plant on fresh product,
withdrawing from frozen. The impact on profits is expected to
be minimal given the low margin on the business currently
and action taken to reduce overheads. The company continues to be optimistic regarding its pipeline of new business, particularly in fresh
